newsitem.title: LATVIA: BEARISH MARKET TO TURN BULLISH, ANALYST SAYS.
newsitem.headline: BEARISH MARKET TO TURN BULLISH, ANALYST SAYS.

text.p: Low liquidity and a loss of faith among domestic investors have steadily been taking a bite out of Lithuanian shares but the bears may soon be attacked by bulls, an investment conference was told on Thursday.

"For the short-term, the market will stay bearish...but in the long-term, it will certainly become bullish," Tomas Andrejauskas of Lithuanian broker Suprema told a conference on fund management and investment in the Baltics.
Lithuania's market, like Latvia and Estonia, has been volatile since the start of the year.
Prices soared to record highs in January but the trend, with a few hicups, has been downhill ever since.

Andrejauskas said that there were three main factors behind the market's volatility: low liquidity, a loss of confidence on the part of domestic investors and the bourse's order-driven system which fixes one price per day.
"There is not enough liquidity in the market and confidence by domestic investors is down from earlier this year," he said.
Analysts say January's bull run was speculative and fuelled by domestic investors, some of whom were in for a quick return.
But Andrejauskas said that things looked set to get better.
"There are some very good opportunities right now while prices are undervalued," he said.
"There are great opportunities to take part in the privatisation of large-scale companies...which will be listed on the bourse," he added.
He also noted that macroeconomic factors bode well for the market's future.
"Political instability is a thing of the past," he said, noting all major political parties were committed to reform.
He also noted that the country's economy was expanding while inflation was falling.
Lithuania's economy is believed to have grown by around 3.6 percent last year and the government predicts that it will increase a further five percent this year.
